title.narrative: Marine Turtle Conservation Fund

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to support a hawksbill conservation program along the Caribbean Nicaragua coast. Under this Award the Recipient will conduct daily hawksbill nest surveys in the Pearl Keys on 8 keys and twice weekly surveys on 4 additional keys, survey mainland hawksbill nesting beaches at El Cocal, and work with local communities to develop procedures and protocols for tourist turtle watching activities.

title.narrative: Marine Turtle Conservation Fund

description.narrative: The recipient will monitor and protect leatherback and hawksbill nesting populations through community protection strategies at Veracruz, Salamina, and Estero Padre Ramos, strengthen coastal management and protection of nesting sites at Salamina and Estero Padre Ramos by by raising awareness of policy makers and local stakeholders and by implementing a National Sea Turtle Campaign at the nesting beaches, and develop a conservation tourism program at Estero Padre Ramos.

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund

title.narrative: Marine Turtle Conservation Fund

description.narrative: The recipient will 1. monitor and evaluate beach and nest temperatures in hatcheries and on nesting beach, 2. evaluate and compare hatchling sex ratios in hatcheries and in situ nests, 3. evaluate predation of hatchlings from arribada nesting and solitary nesting, 4. evaluate type and abundance of predators at Rancho Nuevo nesting beach, 5. evaluate emergence rate and survival rate to sea of hatchlings from arribada nests and solitary nests, and 6. evaluate hatchling emergence times in hatcheries and in situ.

title.narrative: Strengthening Conservation of Critically Endangered Leatherback and Hawksbill Marine Turtles on Nicaraguas Pacific Coast

description.narrative: The recipient will monitor and protect leatherback and hawksbill nesting populations through community protection strategies at Asseradores, Veracruz, Salamina, and Estero Padre Ramos, strengthen coastal management and protection of nesting sites at Salamina, Veracruz, and Estero Padre Ramos by raising awareness of policy makers and local stakeholders and by implementing a National Sea Turtle Campaign at the nesting beaches, and develop a conservation tourism program at Estero Padre Ramos. The USFWS will work closely with grantee in setting goals, priorities, and developing budgets, and will provide assistance as needed and requested in engaging with National Governmental and other institutions to improve collaboration and conservation outcomes.

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund

title.narrative: A comprehensive approach to recovery of hawksbill turtles in the Eastern Pacific: Protecting one of the last remaining nesting strongholds and spearheading reduction of catastrophic bycatch at critical foraging grounds

description.narrative: The recipient will work with local communities to build teams to patrol 40 km of hawkbsill nesting beaches from April 15 - October 15 to protect nests through relocation to hatcheries using best management practices, conduct education outreach activities with local communities including an annual Hawksbill Festival "Day of the Hawksbill" activities in local schools, work with local communities to develop eco tourism activities, collect data on lobster fisheries and hawksbill bycatch, and work with local fisherman to develop strategies to reduce hawksbill bycatch . The USFWS will work closely with grantee in setting goals, priorities, and developing budgets, and will also provide assistance as needed and requested in engaging with National Governmental and other institutions to improve collaboration and conservation outcomes.

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund
U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund
U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund

title.narrative: Re-activating the Indio-Maiz Biosphere's Forest Ranger Program to Stop Illegal Cattle Ranching..Encroachment and Poaching

description.narrative: Project activities will stabilize illegal cattle ranching and poaching in the Indio-Maz Biosphere Reserve by coordinating with the Rama people, the national Ministry of Natural Resource and the Environment (MARENA) and the Autonomous Secretariat of Natural Resources (SERENA) to develop and implement a sustainable community-based forest ranger program. Project will: 1) conduct stakeholder meetings to complete a threat-identification and priority setting exercise and establish patrol routes, 2) train and activate four groups of five indigenous forest rangers and an indigenous data manager for each group to process and analyze data then disseminate results, 3) set up a payment system for forest rangers and 4) work with authorities to monitor patrolling results and ensure follow-up enforcement action.

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

title.narrative: Conserving a newly discovered population of the critically endangered robber frog Craugastor raonides in an amphibian crossroads" in Southwestern Nicaragua

description.narrative: Conserving a newly discovered population of the critically endangered robber frog Craugastor raonides in an amphibian "crossroadsin Nicaragua. In partnership with Paso Pacifico, this project will conduct repeated surveys to establish the size, population dynamics, and distribution of C. raniodes and C. Laevissimus. Outreach and educational activities will also be conducted with community members and landowners.

U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund

title.narrative: FULL LIFE-CYCLE CONSERVATION FOR TWO LISTED BIRD SPECIES

description.narrative: Nicaragua is Central America's largest country and harbors some of the best quality tracts of dry forest between Mexico and Costa Rica, making it of critical importance for the conservation of neotropical migratory birds. A full life-cycle approach is needed to effectively conserve neotropical migratory birds. However, a lack of information on the non-breeding ecology of many species of conservation concern hampers effective conservation. The western yellow-billed cuckoo and the southwestern willow flycatcher have experienced substantial population declines, leading to conservation and restoration efforts. This project will contribute to the conservation of the southwestern willow flycatcher and the western yellow-billed cuckoo by locating key overwintering and migratory habitat sites, measuring the presence of these bird species at those sites, and by linking the migrating and wintering populations at these key sites with breeding sites in North America. These applied research efforts will be carried out in parallel with conservation actions focused on restoring and protecting habitat areas, and will build capacity for migratory bird conservation through targeted training to local biologists and through environmental education. This project will improve protection for migratory birds through private lands through establishment of a reserve and partnering with dozens of farmers to restore habitat. ..Additional species that will benefit include: olive-sided flycatcher, cerulean warbler, worm-eating warbler, elegant trogon, and Canada warbler.....

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Neotropical Migratory Bird Conservation

title.narrative: Conserving Critically Endangered Leatherback and Hawksbill Marine Turtles on Nicaraguas Pacific Coast.

description.narrative: The recipient will monitor and protect leatherback and hawksbill nesting populations through community protection strategies at Asseradores, Veracruz, Salamina, and Estero Padre Ramos, strengthen coastal management and protection of nesting sites at Salamina, Veracruz, and Estero Padre Ramos by raising awareness of policy makers and local stakeholders and by implementing a National Sea Turtle Campaign at the nesting beaches, and develop a conservation tourism program at Estero Padre Ramos. The recipient will conduct rapid bycatch assessments at five priority sites along the Nicaraguan Pacific coast and promote the use of low-impact fishing methods.

title.narrative: Saving Nicaraguas Indio-Maz Biological Reserve By Empowering its Indigenous and Autonomous Authorities

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to build a self-sustaining, effective, professional forest ranger program with the indigenous Rama and afro-descendant Kriol peoples of the Indio-Maz Biological Reserve in southeastern Nicaragua. The project is intended to conserve lowland tropical rainforests and threatened species, such as great green macaws, Bairds Tapirs, and jaguars from the advancing illegal cattle ranching frontier and uncontrolled timber and wildlife extraction. Specific activities include: (1) support patrols of trained, professional indigenous and afro-descendant rangers; (2) help Rama and Kriol leaders diversify their responses to threats identified in the reserve; (3) develop the institutional capacity and financial literacy of the Rama and Kriol communal governments needed to manage the ranger program in the future; (4) facilitate the adoption of a SMART database by regional natural resources authorities; and (5) work with the IUCN World Commission on Protected Areas to facilitate the writing of a new management plan for Indio Maz that formally integrates the Rama and Kriol ranger program into regional level protected area management.

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Resource Management
U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Resource Management
U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Resource Management
U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Resource Management

title.narrative: FULL LIFE-CYCLE CONSERVATION FOR TWO LIS

description.narrative: A lack of information on the non-breeding ecology of the Southwestern Willow Flycatcher (WIFL) (an endangered species) and Western Yellow-billed Cuckoo (a threatened species) prevents effective conservation in their wintering grounds on the Pacific slope of Nicaragua. Both species have experienced substantial population declines and partners seek to better understand the migratory routes, overwintering areas, habitat preferences, and survival rates of these two threatened species. Partners will measure these bird's presence at key sites in Nicaragua, and link migrating and wintering populations at these sites with breeding sites in North America as well as use remote sensing modeling to identify WIFL wintering habitat throughout western Nicaragua. These applied research efforts will accompany conservation actions to restore and protect habitat areas, and will build capacity for migratory bird conservation through targeted training to local biologists and through environmental education. This project will improve protection for migratory birds on private lands where partners will increase a new 60 hectare reserve and add another 200 hectares of private protected areas for bird conservation, work with farmers to restore 20 hectares of riparian habitat and work closely with farmers and ranchers to improve habitat on 1000 hectares through a range of land management strategies.

activity-date.narrative: Date unavailable. Calculated start date is the earliest transaction date

title.narrative: Conservation of Hawksbill Turtles Along the Southeast Coast of Nicaragua

description.narrative: The long term goal is the recovery and long-term conservation of the El Cocal hawksbill rookery. To work towards this goal we propose a multi-year program (2018-2021) that will improve monitoring, reduce threats, and build capacity at the local level. It is vital to increase local capacity to take over management of the program and continue conservation measures and monitoring of sea turtle rookeries at El Cocal.

activity-date.narrative: Date unavailable. Calculated start date is the earliest transaction date

title.narrative: Conservation of Hawksbill Turtles Along the Southeast Coast of Nicaragua

description.narrative: The long term goal is the recovery and long-term conservation of the El Cocal hawksbill rookery. To work towards this goal we propose a multi-year program (2018-2021) that will improve monitoring, reduce threats, and build capacity at the local level. It is vital to increase local capacity to take over management of the program and continue conservation measures and monitoring of sea turtle rookeries at El Cocal.

activity-date.narrative: Date unavailable. Calculated start date is the earliest transaction date

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund

title.narrative: Conservation of Hawksbill Turtles Along the Southeast Coast of Nicaragua

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to conduct a community based sea turtle conservation project along 36 km of hawksbill nesting beach between the mouths of the Karaslaya and Indio/San Juan rivers which hosts some of the most important hawksbill nesting in Caribbean Nicaragua. The intent of this project is to protect nests and nesting turtles from poaching. Activities include: (1) training local community members to conduct twice weekly surveys during May through October along 36 km of nesting beach to count nests and deter poaching: (2) conduct a seven day field and classroom Sea Turtle Course for four upper class students and a faculty member from Blue Fields Indian and Caribbean University: (3) conduct outreach, education and awareness activities with educational, municipal and communal authorities and local communities.

title.narrative: CONSERVATION OF HAWKSBILL TURTLES ALONG THE SOUTHEAST COAST OF NICARAGUA (II)

description.narrative: THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO IMPLEMENT A COMMUNITY-BASED SEA TURTLE CONSERVATION PROJECT BETWEEN THE MOUTHS OF THE KARASLAYA AND INDIO SAN JUAN RIVERS, AN AREA WHICH HOSTS THE MOST IMPORTANT HAWKSBILL NESTING IN CARIBBEAN NICARAGUA. THE INTENT OF THIS PROJECT IS TO PROTECT NESTS AND NESTING TURTLES FROM POACHING. ACTIVITIES INCLUDE 1 TRAINING LOCAL COMMUNITY MEMBERS TO CONDUCT TWICE-WEEKLY SURVEYS FROM MAY THROUGH OCTOBER ALONG 36 KM OF THE EL COCAL NESTING BEACH TO COUNT NESTS AND DETER POACHING 2 CONDUCTING AN EIGHT-DAY FIELD AND CLASSROOM-BASED SEA TURTLE COURSE FOR FOUR STUDENTS AND A FACULTY MEMBER FROM BLUE FIELDS INDIAN AND CARIBBEAN UNIVERSITY AND 3 CONDUCTING OUTREACH, EDUCATION, AND AWARENESS ACTIVITIES WITH MUNICIPAL AND COMMUNAL AUTHORITIES AND LOCAL COMMUNITIES. EL COCAL IS RELATIVELY UNDERDEVELOPED AND REMOTE, AND MAY MIGRATE INLAND AS SEA-LEVEL RISES, BECOMING A POSSIBLE CRITICAL NESTING REFUGE.

title.narrative: MARINE TURTLE CONSERVATION FUND - 2021

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to implement a community-based sea turtle conservation project between.the mouths of the Karaslaya and Indio/San Juan rivers, an area which hosts the most important hawksbill.nesting in Caribbean Nicaragua. The intent of this project is to protect nests and nesting turtles from.poaching. Activities include: (1) training local community members to conduct twice-weekly surveys.from May through October along 36 km of the El Cocal nesting beach to count nests and deter poaching:.(2) conducting an eight-day field and classroom-based sea turtle course for four students and a faculty.member from Blue Fields Indian and Caribbean University; and (3) conducting outreach, education, and.awareness activities with municipal and communal authorities and local communities. El Cocal is.relatively underdeveloped and remote, and may migrate inland as sea-level rises, becoming a possible.critical nesting refuge.

title.narrative: CONSERVING CRITICALLY ENDANGERED LEATHERBACK & HAWKSBILL MARINE TURTLES ON NICARAGUA S PACIFIC COAST (II)

description.narrative: THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO IMPLEMENT NESTING BEACH CONSERVATION PROGRAMS FOR AN EAST PACIFIC LEATHERBACK NESTING POPULATION, AND TO SUPPORT AN EASTERN PACIFIC HAWKSBILL CONSERVATION PROGRAM AT TWO RECENTLY DISCOVERED NESTING SITES AT ESTERO PADRE RAMOS AND ASERRADORES. POACHING OF NESTS AND ACCIDENTAL CAPTURE IN FISHERIES ARE THE GREATEST THREATS TO THESE POPULATIONS. ACTIVITIES INCLUDE: (1) CONDUCTING DAILY COMMUNITY-BASED SURVEYS TO COUNT AND PROTECT NESTS AND NESTING FEMALES AND TO RELOCATE EGGS TO HATCHERIES (2) PROVIDING TRAINING WORKSHOPS FOR THE SURVEY TEAMS (3) WORKING WITH FISHERS TO REDUCE INCIDENTAL BYCATCH AND TRAINING THEM IN SAFE HANDLING AND RELEASE METHODS AND (4) CONDUCTING ENVIRONMENTAL EDUCATION AND OUTREACH ACTIVITIES WITH LOCAL COMMUNITIES, INCLUDING A DAY OF THE TURTLE EVENT IN SCHOOLS AND THE ANNUAL HAWKSBILL CUP COMPETITION WITH THE HAWKSBILL PROJECT IN EL SALVADOR.

activity-date.narrative: Date unavailable. Calculated start date is the earliest transaction date

title.narrative: RESTORING KEY HABITAT OF NEARCTIC MIG BI

description.narrative: This project seeks to address the threats to areas still available for dozens of neotropical migratory bird species in the Bosawas Biosphere Reserve (BBR), a priority 'Birdscape' for the long-term conservation of neotropical migratory bird populations. The main objectives are to increase the availability of habitat for, and the diversity of, Nearctic migratory bird species in the BBR and to strengthen law enforcement and governance in priority conservation areas. Partners will work closely with local communities to restore areas degraded by unstainable practices and extensive cattle ranching, as well as to implement agroforestry and silvopastoral systems that will also improve local livelihoods and contribute to climate change adaptation and mitigation. This will be accomplished by signing Conservation Agreements with targeted communities, to restore 10,000 hectares in priority landscapes in the BBR, and improve productive management across 600 hectares. Partners will build local capacities for a better institutional and community-based governance, based on a robust monitoring system for direct measuring of impacts on Nearctic migratory bird communities, including the first Monitoring of Winter Survival stations in this region, with support and involvement of local institutions and authorities for community outreach and education. Lastly, they will train and conduct patrols to identify and deter illegal activities in priority landscapes for restoration in BBR, and support negotiations between communities and encroachers for their voluntary retreat from the illegally occupied territories. Overall, the project will impact a 10,000-hectare landscape in which they will develop migratory bird-friendly agroforestry systems, recover degraded pasture or deforested lands and increase protection to ensure long term changes in forest conditions.

activity-date.narrative: Date unavailable. Calculated start date is the earliest transaction date

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry
